answers.answer: Congratulations on your excellent A1C. I'm also a type 1 (LADA) and so far the lowest I've gotten mine is 6.3. I am also a vegetarian and realized I had to make a lot of changes in my diet when I was diagnosed. I heard that many people weren't able to maintain a vegetarian diet as diabetics and was willing to change if I had to for my health, but was glad I didn't have to. I don't eat very low carb (I'm sure my A1C would be lower if I did) but moderate low and I do a lot of cooking, so I can have interesting meals but not too high carb.As for your question, I'm not an exerciser so I don't really have any suggestions. But I am on a website with a lot more traffic from longterm type 1's and many discussions about just this topic. I'm not allowed to post websites on here so I'm sending you a PM with the address. Keep up the good work!

question: Hello!  I am a Type 1 Diabetic, 28 year old woman, and was diagnosed when I was 9.  I have always tried to keep on top of my blood sugars, and have maintained a Hemoglobin A1C of 6 or below for years, using a combination of Lantus and Humalog injections.  Currently, I take 15 units of Lantus, and Humalog on a sliding scale.  I am a vegetarian, mostly vegan, and eat a diet based on a large amount of fruits and vegetables and hardly any refined foods (maybe whole grains 2 or 3 times a week, no refined sugars, etc.)I have always been physically active, but recently lost a lot of weight (I was out of the country and didn't have food), which seemed to make me more insulin-sensitive.  However, I have begun exercising much more intensely, and my blood sugar is spiking like crazy after exercise.  I will take it before going on a run, it will be 80, I will come back, having ingested nothing but water, and it will be 290.  The same with capoeira.  So, I have to take more Humalog just to bring it down, and sometimes I then go low...  I don't want to be on this rollercoaster, and I am wondering what I can adjust/do so that I can continue to be active, train hard, lose weight, and not take a ton of insulin.  I don't want my A1Cs to be off!  I want to stay in control.  I am also familiar with the research on intense exercise and hyperglycemia, but that research doesn't really give direction as to how to deal with the problem...Thank you.
title: Type I Diabetes and Post-Exercise Hyperglycemia
